A great place to start is at the CNA, or certified nurses assistant level. CNA's are considered non-technical staff, but provide basic patient care under the direction of nurse supervisors. CNA positions offer a wealth of experience for those wishing to work toward other positions in the medical field. Their responsibilities can include taking vitals, assisting patients who have mobility issues, responding to call lights, making beds, and monitoring food intake. Typically, certified nurse assistants earn from $18,000-$24,000 a year.Another important characteristic of a nurse that is sometimes overlooked is the ability to understand people. Nurses are put into a difficult position because they generally are dealing with people who have been put under an extraordinary amount of pain or stress or a combination of the two. While you may not have personally been in that situation, being a nurse forces you to put yourself in that person's shoes and understand where they are coming from. People in these dire circumstances may not always be the nicest people in the world. For the astute nurse, this is alright.
